text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with grilled jerk pork tenderloin
that's right we're taking the same
amazing caribbean spice blend that you
know and love from chicken and applying
it to the OE x' user-friendly pork
tenderloin and is it as good
well i don't want to sound like a jerk
but it might be better so here's how we
do it we're gonna get our fresh
ingredients together first i have some
fresh thyme you can use dry but i like
the fresh some minced ginger a little
bit of onion some garlic and of course
i'm hot pepper
traditionally we're gonna use scotch
bonnet for this but I'm using habanero
which is basically the same thing so
either one scotch bonnet or habanero
both very fruity and extremely hot so
that's what you want now as far as how
many to put in use one if you're normal
two if you're crazy three if you're
insane and four if you want to be like
chef John you're gonna want to cut those
in half and take out the seeds before
you throw them in here so we're gonna
toss all that in the blender and we're
also gonna add our fresh thyme some
white distilled vinegar some soy sauce
some vegetable oil alright some brown
sugar for a little sweetness I don't
know why it tastes so good some salt
some freshly ground black pepper some
cayenne of course and then the jerkiest
of all the jerk spices ground allspice
please do not substitute most spice or
some spice you want to get the allspice
mandatory ingredient all right Ross can
add some freshly grated nutmeg and last
but not least some ground cinnamon
alright we're gonna take that over and
we're gonna blend that until completely
smooth and you know I always recommend
stopping to scrape down once or twice so
we're gonna process that until
completely smooth and by the way in case
you're wondering the name jerk seasoning
is kind of a mystery there's many
theories on how that name came to be the
one I like the best is it was invented
originally by jerks alright and right
there that's looking perfect so we're
gonna turn that off and we're gonna
reserve that until our pork is prepped
which is the next task so we have two
pork tenderloins they're pretty much
trimmed and ready to go although you do
have to take off a little bit of that
silver skin and you've seen us do this
many times
take a sharp thin knife stick it right
underneath the silver skin being careful
not to angle your knife into the meat
and that stuff should come off fairly
easily you don't have to go too precise
just get most of it off all right so
we're gonna clean
once those are fully trimmed I'm going
to show you a trick of how I like to cut
this for the grill so a pork tenderloin
has two ends it has kind of a flat
tapered end and then more of a fat
rounded end so I want you to find that
thinner flatter tapered end which is to
our right and I want you to make a cut
almost halfway okay so there's one piece
then you're gonna be left with a fatter
piece of pork that I'm gonna cut
lengthwise in half like that
and if I flattened those two pieces out
a little bit I have three pieces that
are just about the same size thickness
density etc and that means it's gonna
cook evenly on the grill and there you
go
so two pork tenderloins are gonna give
us six and nice portions we're gonna go
ahead and transfer the pork into a
sealable plastic bag pour over our jerk
marinade and then give it a good massage
not one of these lights touchy-feely
sports therapy massages I'm talking deep
tissue make my masseuse helga proud
which by the way is not easy she's she's
quite terrifying once the meat is
completely coated with the marinade
we're gonna put that in the fridge for a
marination period of between four and
six hours of course you can go longer
but then you're on your own
I think overnight would be over
marinated but that's up to you but I'm
officially suggesting four to six hours
for the maximum marination sensation and
six hours later mine was ready to grill
so I pulled it out of the marinade I
wiped off all the excess you can have a
little bit on the surface but you don't
want to stop and wet some people like to
reese's him before they put it on the
grill here I don't think it's necessary
so I'm putting mine straight onto my
preheated very hot very clean very
well-seasoned grates all right so I'm
gonna place those down and then very
important not to touch them for at least
five or six minutes any time you're
grilling meat that has a wet rub on it
or a marinade it's really gonna want to
stick so if you try to pull it up right
away you're gonna tear the meat don't do
it just let it sit there and like magic
five or six minutes later that meats
gonna tighten up those grill marks are
gonna form and it's gonna release from
the grill just like that all right and
stuff like this I can't really give you
a time's mine went for about six seven
minutes aside but really you're gonna
want to go by temperature 145 perfectly
safe for pork tenderloin do
overcook your pork tenderloin personally
I'd rather get food poisoning than eat
dry pork but that's just me all right
and then one other tip here is these get
close to being done I like to kind of
move them around so the thickest end of
the pork is facing the hottest part of
the grill all right so you're always
gonna have hot spots when you're using
charcoal like this so I like to move my
meat around it just makes it a little
less likely you're gonna overcook those
thinner parts all right and then right
there I decided mine are done I'm taking
them off of course you're gonna let this
rest at least five minutes and while
you're letting them rest you can figure
out how to plate I went with some
additional fresh thyme and some fried
plantain chips which I thought made a
nice presentation and of course if you
followed my directions to a tea you're
gonna be looking at some extremely
gorgeous juicy perfect pork look at that
see that little bit of a pink blush that
means this is not overcooked and you're
gonna be tasting some spectacular pork
tenderloin I decided to serve mine with
some black beans and rice a few extra
plantain chips and I actually was
thinking of putting a Saul's on this
like a mango salsa to garnish but I
decided to taste it first it was so
amazing so tender so flavorful I didn't
even make a sauce I just ate it like
this and juicy texture aside the flavor
was really really nice spicy aromatic
interesting just everything you want
from a grilled meat so I really hope you
give this a try head over to food watch
Escom for all the ingredient amounts and
more info as usual and as always enjoy
you
